table.name: mem
table.column: This is a shortened form of {Qu'vatlh:excl}.

table.name: mem
table.column: An English definition has never been given for this word. Its meaning is inferred from the only example of its usage.
▶ {Qo'noS romuluS je boSuqlaH. vabDot tera' Qejbogh DIvI' ram boSuqlaH.:sen:nolink} "Kronos, Romulus and even the puny Federation's precious Earth, are all up for grabs."[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: There is an expression, {vaDjaj yaDDu'lIj:sen:nolink} "may your toes be flexible", the meaning of which is unclear, but which might be a wish for good fortune.

table.name: mem
table.column: fifth tone of nonatonic musical scale
The tones of the Klingon musical scale (see {yutlhegh:n}) are: {yu:n}, {bIm:n}, {'egh:n}, {loS:n:2}, {vagh:n:2,nolink}, {jav:n:2}, {Soch:n:2}, {chorgh:n:2}, {yu:n:nolink}.

table.name: mem
mem
table.column: {vagh reD mey' HoS:n@@vagh reD mey':n, HoS:v} "regular pentagon"[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This can actually be used for anything that acts as a cover for something one puts inside of it.[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: so, then, thus, in that case
Note that this is not a conjunction, but an adverbial.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word refers to the concept of warriorhood (e.g., "warrior spirit", and so on). To refer to a person who is a warrior, use {SuvwI':n}.[2]
▶ {vaj toDuj Daj ngeHbej DI vI'.:sen} ▶ {vaj Duj chIj:sen:idiom}

table.name: mem
table.column: This idiomatic expression literally means "warrior ship" or "warrior instincts", due to the homophony between {Duj:n:1} and {Duj:n:2}.
▶ {vaj Duj DachIj.:sen:nolink} "You have strength of character."

table.name: mem
table.column: This idiomatic expression literally means "to navigate a warrior ship".
▶ {vaj Duj DachIj.:sen:nolink} "You have strength of character."

table.name: mem
table.column: vaj toDuj Daj ngeHbej DI vI'.
Shooting space garbage is no test of a warrior's mettle.

This is a backfit for the sentence, {vaj toDDujDaj ngeHbej DIvI'.@@vaj:adv, toDDuj:n, -Daj:n, ngeH:v, -bej:v, DIvI':n} "That means the Federation will be sending a rescue ship of its own." Both sentences were spoken by Captain Klaa in {Star Trek V:src}.
The original line was to have been {logh veQDaq bachchugh, yoH 'e' toblaHbe' SuvwI'.@@logh:n, veQ:n, -Daq:n, bach:v, -chugh:v, yoH:v, 'e':n, tob:v, -laH:v, -be':v, SuvwI':n}

table.name: mem
table.column: The 2009 {Star Trek:src} movie has a deleted scene with the line: {tIjwI'ghom bovanrupbe'chugh, vaj reQaw'.:sen:nolink}

table.name: mem
table.column: end (an event, voyage, battle, play, opera, story, song, etc.)

The subject of this verb is the person causing an event to end. The object is the event that is ended. If the event was prematurely brought to an end, use {ghang:v} instead. To describe the ending of a period of time, use {Dor:v:2} instead.

table.name: mem
table.column: A planet in the Gamma Quadrant.

table.name: mem
table.column: vangDI' tlhIngan SuvwI' ngoy' qorDu'Daj; vangDI' qorDu'Daj ngoy' tlhIngan SuvwI'.
The family of a Klingon warrior is responsible for his actions, and he is responsible for theirs.

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {bI'reS qeylIS vaq molor:sen:nolink} "First, Molor taunts Kahless"[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a planet in the Klingon Empire in which native languages have survived alongside Klingon.
This word appears only in the body of {KGT:src}, and in English, but the original Klingon name is obvious.

table.name: mem
table.column: be aggressive, be effective, be vigorous
This word was originally used in describing weapons, but is now also applied to people. It has strongly positive connotations in slang.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the seat of the Klingon government.

▶ {juHqo'Daq vaS'a' tu'lu'. ngoch luchermeH 'ej wo' San luwuqmeH pa' ghom tlhIngan yejquv DevwI'pu'. DaH che' ghawran. yejquv DevwI' moj ghawran 'e' wuqta' cho' 'oDwI' Dapu'bogh janluq pIqarD HoD.:sen:nolink} "On the Homeworld, there is a great hall where the leaders of the Klingon High Council meet to determine policy and decide upon the fate of the Empire. Gowron currently presides, named leader of the High Council by Captain Jean-Luc Picard, who was acting as Arbiter of Succession."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {cha'maH vagh vatlhvI' Hong, QIt yIghoS.:sen:nolink} "Slow to one quarter impulse."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: To indicate "centuries ago" or "centuries from now", {ret:n} and {pIq:n} are used in place of {poH:n}, respectively.[3]
The sentence from {SkyBox 15:src} has the {wa'DIch:n} in the wrong place. Also, the second occurrence of {vatlh DIS poH:n} is missing a space.

table.name: mem
table.column: The siblings of a {vav:n} are {tennuS:n} and {'e'mam:n}.

The joke with {vav:n:nolink} and {SoS:n:nolink} is that in most human languages, the words for "father" and "mother" contain simple labial sounds (typically either "b" or "p" for father, and "m" for mother), whereas the fricatives {v:sen:nolink} and {S:sen:nolink} are difficult sounds for human infants to make.

table.name: mem
table.column: In ascending order of ferocity, the verbs used to describe military confrontations are: {Qor:v}, {tlhaS:v}, {vay:v:nolink}, {lul:v}, {Hargh:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: To express an indefinite subject, see {-lu':v:suff}.

table.name: mem
table.column: To refer to the next day, month, or year, consider using {leS:n}, {waQ:n}, and {nem:n}, respectively.
While {nungbogh:v:nolink} precedes a noun, {veb:v:nolink} comes after one.

table.name: mem
table.column: The plural of this word is {veDDIrmey:n:nolink} rather than {veDDIrDu':n:nolink}.[1; 2]

table.name: mem
table.column: go through (an open door, a tunnel, etc.)

This verb only means to go through an opening of some sort, and not "to traverse" (in the sense of "going through" a forest).[1] The object is the thing being gone through. {-Daq:n:suff} is unnecessary.[2]
[1] {HQ 6.3, p.5-8, Sept. 1997:src}, [2] {HQ 7.4, Dec. 1998:src}, [3] {Klingon Monopoly:src}, [4] {paq'batlh:src}, [5] {KLI mailing list 2013.07.29:src}

table.name: mem
table.column: The text of {SkyBox 99:src} reads: ▶ {loS... qIb HeHDaq, 'u' SepmeyDaq Sovbe'lu'bogh lenglu'meH He ghoSlu'bogh retlhDaq 'oHtaH. HaDlu'meH, QuSlu'meH, SuDlu'meH lojmIt Da logh Hop Hut tengchaH. vaj loghDaq lenglaHtaH Humanpu'. veH Qav 'oH logh'e'.:sen:nolink}

table.name: mem
table.column:
The subject does the covering, while the object is covered.
This verb is used to describe the laying of a carpet. The person who lays a carpet is called a {velwI':n:nolink} (despite the fact that the grammar suggests that {velwI':n:nolink} would refer to the carpet itself).
▶ {rav vel tlhIm.:sen:nolink} "The carpet covers the floor." ▶ {rav velmeH tlhIm lo'.:sen:nolink} "He lays the carpet on the floor."

table.name: mem
table.column: In {Klingon Monopoly:src}, the "Chancellor's Cane Replica" is referred to as {Qang naQ velqa':n:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: print, mark, tracks, trace, image, pattern

This refers to the trace or marks left behind by touch, such as (the image of) a fingerprint, tire tracks, or the pattern in the dirt that results from stepping on it.
This word is contrasted with {Su'nIm:n} which refers to the pattern that makes the {vem:n:nolink}. But {Su'nIm:n:nolink} is used only when it's something very detailed which leaves the {vem:n:nolink}. For example, compare {nItlh Su'nIm:n@@nItlh:n, Su'nIm:n} "fingerprint" (ridges on fingertip) with {nItlh Su'nIm vem:n@@nItlh:n, Su'nIm:n, vem:n} "fingerprint" (mark left behind after touching).
Note that an intentionally produced, stamp-like image is a {yang:n}.
In the following examples, the specific finger or toe name can be used instead of {nItlh:n} (or {yaD:n:1}).

▶ {nItlh Su'nIm vem:n@@nItlh:n, Su'nIm:n, vem:n} fingerprint (mark left behind after touching) ▶ {bem Su'nIm vem:n@@bem:n, Su'nIm:n, vem:n} footprint (specific pattern of bottom of shoe) ▶ {bem vem:n@@bem:n, vem:n} footprint (basic outline of a foot left in dirt) ▶ {namwech vem:n@@namwech:n, vem:n} paw print (pattern left in dirt)

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a bird that feeds almost exclusively on the serpent worm from which {qagh:n} is made. Klingons are not particularly fond of this bird.
An early bird catches the worm.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word describes someone who is really into something (or a number of things), who partakes in activities associated with it, and does so very seriously.
"Fan", or possibly a reference to a Venn diagram where "nerd" is at the intersection of "intelligence", "obsession", and "social ineptitude".

table.name: mem
table.column:
This word describes someone who is really into something (or a number of things), who partakes in activities associated with it, and does so very seriously.
A more common term for this is {qatru':n:nolink}.

table.name: mem
mem
table.column: This word appears only in the body of {KGT:src} and not in the glossary.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word appears only in the body of {KGT:src} and not in the glossary.

table.name: mem
table.column: There is an idiom, {qej; veqlargh rur}.

table.name: mem
table.column: You pay attention to your Fek'lhr and I will pay attention to mine.
Du passt auf deinen Fek'lhr auf und ich achte auf meinen.

table.name: mem
table.column: Your ship is a garbage scow.

table.name: mem
table.column: Ferengis are known for their greed, as reflected in the comparison {qur; verengan rur}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the name of the Ferengi Homeworld, the primary planet in the Ferengi Alliance.

table.name: mem
table.column:
The object is the vehicle that is docked.[3]
In {Klingon Monopoly:src}, "Free Parking" is translated as {vergh 'ach DIlnISbe':sen:nolink}.
▶ {nuqDaq puH Duj vIvergh?:sen:nolink} "Where can I park the car?"[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: Contrast this with {noH:n}, which refers to a specific war.

table.name: mem
table.column: From lowest to highest, these ranks are: {tay:n:2}, {Sutay:n}, {veStay:n:nolink}, {Santay:n}, {'Iptay:n}.
This is a rank from John M. Ford's 1984 novel "The Final Reflection". These ranks are used by many Klingon fan clubs, despite not appearing in canon (i.e., in any TV episode or movie).

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {veymey puS neH chenmoHlu'pu':sen:nolink} "Limited Edition" ▶ {boSwI'vaD veyvam le' chenmoHlu':sen:nolink} "Collector's Edition" ▶ {wa' tlhIngan QaS vey:n:nolink} "one pack of Klingon forces"

table.name: mem
table.column: travel with a purpose, for a specific reason; travel on a mission
mit einer Absicht bzw. Mission reisen
The example sentence is a lip-match for {DevwI' ghaH 'Iv'e'?@@DevwI':n, ghaH:n, 'Iv:ques, -'e':n:suff}.
▶ {jIvuylaH. jIve'.} "I am here to help you."

table.name: mem
table.column:
{jIH:n:1h}:{ghaH:n}/{'oH:n}/{chaH:n}/{bIH:n} = {vI-:v:pref,nolink}
When used with {-lu':v}, this prefix means "Someone (indefinite subject) does something to me".

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a device that regulates the flow of gas, sound, etc.

table.name: mem
table.column: type of animal, v'gro (like a cat)
"Figuro" is the name of the cat in Disney's Pinocchio.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This verb is intransitive. To say that someone or something moves someone or something else, use {vIHmoH:v:nolink}.[2]
For an idiomatic expression used to tell someone not to move, see {taD:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This idiomatic expression means that an activity of finite (though perhaps indeterminate) length has started.
▶ {bISop DaneH'a'? vIHtaH gho.:sen:nolink} "If you want to eat, say so now before the food is gone."

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to a concept in computer programming, namely, a segment of code which is repeatedly executed until some condition is met.

table.name: mem
table.column: someone or something who is just there; someone who is around when you are
When this word was defined at {qep'a' 2009:src}, a description of an object which was recognised as a "speed bump" was given as an example of a {vIl:n:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: The suggestion was made at {qep'a' 2009:src} that a {vIlHom:n:nolink} could be a single ridge in a {Quch:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a bird capable of mimicking speech. Some people pluralize this word with {-pu':n:suff}, but most use {-mey:n:suff}.
This is a reference to Captain Flint, Long John Silver's parrot in "Treasure Island".

table.name: mem
table.column: In the singular, typically {tey':n:nolink} or {lor:n:nolink} is preferred unless the individual is being referred to as a member of a group that likely includes both {tey':n:nolink} and/or {lor:n:nolink}. The plural form {vInpu':n:nolink} is used for a group that includes {tey':n:nolink} and/or {lor:n:nolink}.
A reference to the movie "My Cousin Vinny".

table.name: mem
table.column: compatriot, community member, cohort, fellow citizen
Landsmann, Mitbürger, Mitglied der Mannschaft oder der Truppe
The example sentence is a lip-match for {'ej DochmeywIj vItlhapqa'meH}.
▶ {'ej Dojmey wID, vInDa'ma' peq.} "He has killed many of our people."

table.name: mem
table.column: This word refers to the abstract concept of combat. A specific battle is a {may':n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: It's not specified whether this is a noun or a verb, but it's likely to be a noun, even though {Hay':n:nolink,hyp} is not known to exist as a noun.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is any liquid from a plant. In some regional dialects, this word is used for any liquid accompanying food.
"V8" is a juice blend made from tomato juice mixed with the juices of various vegetables.

table.name: mem
table.column: Earwax (see {Serrum:n}) is said to do this in the ear.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {cha' vI' vagh choQmey lutoghlu':sen:nolink} "Number of Decks: 2.5" {BoP:src}

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to meat prepared by {HaH:v:2}. The word for the specific meat replaces the word {Ha'DIbaH:n:1}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word can be the object of {wel:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is used in {Klingon Monopoly:src} to denote how many {QaS:n:1h} the player receives for mortgaging a planet to the bank.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a reference to Captain "von Trapp" from The Sound of Music, who was played by Christopher Plummer, who of course was also General Chang ({cheng:n:name}).

table.name: mem
table.column: This slang term is not used in reference to games, but is applied only to more serious matters.[1, p.165]
Note that in the example, the prefix {bI-:v} is used rather than {Da-:v}. This might indicate that the apparent {-lu':v} suffix is a fossilized form and isn't truly the suffix.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word appears to consist of the verb {voQ:v} (or a homophonous but unknown noun) and {SIp:n}, so it means something like "choking gas".

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {Hoch vor Dargh wIb.:sen:nolink} "Sour tea cures everything."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: It is unclear why Federation Standard corrupted the spelling of this word by moving the {qaghwI':n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word appears only in the body of {KGT:src} and not in the glossary.

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {QIStaq qul bIQtIqHomDaq 'etlhDaj vo' nuch:sen:nolink} "The coward throws his sword into the fire streams of Kri'stak"[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: Cowards take hostages. Klingons do not.

table.name: mem
mem
table.column:
Vulcans are also sometimes called Vulcanians in English.[2]
Note that this is {vulqangan:n:nolink} and not {vulqanngan:n:nolink} (the {n:sen:nolink} at the end of {vulqan:n:nolink} is dropped).
There is a Klingon idiom, {nong; vulqangan rur}, which is meant ironically.

table.name: mem
table.column: contemptible or despicable person, scumbag, bastard
verächtliche oder verabscheuungswürdige Person, Drecksack, Bastard
The first part of the example sentence was a lip-match for {mughojmoH parmaqqaywI'}. The second part was a lip-match for a sentence beginning with {naDevvo'}.
▶ {potlhmo' batlh, vIqawba', 'ej chIvo' neH chIw vum'e'.} "Because you care about honor. And this man has none."

table.name: mem
mem
table.column: cook, prepare food, make a beverage
The definition in {TKD:src} is just "cook". On {KGT p.83:src}, this is expanded to include the preparation of any food, including beverages. Reverse of {tuv:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to a place where food is prepared.

table.name: mem
table.column: The example sentence is a lip-match for {DevwI' ghaH 'Iv'e'?@@DevwI':n, ghaH:n, 'Iv:ques, -'e':n:suff}.
▶ {jIvuylaH. jIve'.} "I am here to help you."
